data.title: fix #18130
OpenGLES 3 support.
data.body:
A lot of devices have support OpenGLES3, (After iPhone 5S or Android 4.3) .
Could cocos support the ES3 correctly?

If we have ES3, we may be able to take full use of the GPU, and implement the ParticleSystem with `transform feedback` instead of the gl_PointSprite( this have a good performance but lack of scale and rotation). 

We would benefit a lot performance when there were a lot of particles in Scene.

data.title: Android, unpredictable behaviour of onDrawFrame in case of default animation interval
data.body:
- cocos2d-x version: 3.15.1
- devices test on: Samsung Galaxy S7
- developing environments
   - NDK version: 15.2.4203891
   - Android Studio version: 2.3.3

I have noticed following problem in `onDrawFrame` implementation:
`Cocos2dxRenderer.sAnimationInterval` calculated in native code and provided to java via JNI is equal to `16666668` and `(long) 1.0 / 60 * Cocos2dxRenderer.NANOSECONDSPERSECOND` calculated on java side is equal to `16666666`

As result `Cocos2dxRenderer.sAnimationInterval <= 1.0 / 60 * Cocos2dxRenderer.NANOSECONDSPERSECOND` will always be `false` in default (60 FPS) situation and algorithm with `Thread.sleep` will be used. Float is so float.

As an option, you can store animation interval in nanoseconds and safely compare as it as long, or just check that float sAnimationInterval is "approximately equal" to default value.

BTW, I think you can use `Thread.sleep` algorithm in any case. onDrawFrame is called in while(true) and you have 60 calls per second thanks to vsync. On API<16 you can get way more `onDrawFrame` calls, high CPU usage and as result - unstable low fps.

data.title: [Proposal] Use Choreographer on Android for API >= 16 (stable fps)
data.body:
Being inspired by this pull requiest https://github.com/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/pull/17852
I have played with Choreographer on Android platform for some time.
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/Choreographer.FrameCallback.html

Choreographer's callback is called when a new display frame is being rendered and it provides the time in nanoseconds when the frame started being rendered.
This commit illustrates what I'm talking about: https://github.com/PaulDiakov/cocos2d-x/commit/8d12e1558fa00d6343c96c14211fdc63eea79eb0 (without backwards compatibility at this point, consider it as proof of concept)

PROS:
- Frame rate equal to display frame rate by default on all devices with API>=16, without any need of Thread.sleep (RENDERMODE_CONTINUOUSLY does not guarantee that onDrawFrame will be synchronized with refresh cycle of the display).
- Stable and accurate delta time provided by operation system
- Smooth animations without jittering (so far I have tested it on Samsung Galaxy S4, Samsung Galaxy S7 and Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 2014)
- Compatible with native activity https://github.com/googlesamples/android-ndk/blob/master/teapots/choreographer-30fps/src/main/java/com/sample/choreographer/ChoreographerNativeActivity.java (if some day it will be used)

CONS:
- While limitation of animation interval to 30 fps can be easely implemented, something like constant 50 fps may not benefit from Choreographer usage. Maybe Choreographer support can be optional or enabled only for default animation interval?
- Default frame rate will be equal to display refresh rate. I have never seen android devices with refresh rate higher than 60hz, but what do you think about this?

data.title: Fix VAO in CameraBackgroundBrush
data.body:
I'm getting this OpenGL error on Android, once per frame: `I/Adreno-ES20: <validate_vertex_attrib_state:60>: validate_vertex_attrib_state: No vertex attrib is enabled in a draw call!`

These started since #18066 when drawing CameraBackgroundBrush with VAO support. The issue seems to be in `CameraBackgroundDepthBrush::init()` the call to `GL::enableVertexAttribs` that unbinds the VAO.

* Copy `LaunchScreen.storyboard` and `LaunchScreenBackground.png` to `proj.ios` or `ios` folder.

* Set `Launch Screen File` to `LaunchScreen`.
